If a creature with poor eyesight happens to produce offspring with slightly better eyesight, thanks to random mutations, then that tiny bit more vision gives them more chance of survival. The longer they survive, the more chance they have to reproduce and pass on the genes that equipped them with slightly better eyesight. Some of their offspring might, in turn, have better eyesight than their parents, making it likelier that they, too, will reproduce. And so on. Generation by generation, over unfathomably long periods of time, tiny advantages add up. Eventually, after a few hundred million years, you have creatures who can see as well as humans, or cats, or owls.

This is the basic story of evolution, as recounted in countless textbooks and pop-science bestsellers. The problem, according to a growing number of scientists, is that it is absurdly crude and misleading.

Interesting fact about the dyneins and kinesins, they are not as determined to go in one direction as depicted in the graphic. They don’t really ‘know’ which way to go at all. The hydrolysis of ATP causes one of the ‘legs’ to detach and swing in a biased direction. The direction of the swing determines where the leg will bind to again. Since the leg has the highest probability of swinging toward one direction, the net movement will also be in one direction.

I've used Mr. Berry's animations (including this one) in my Science classes for the past several years. What always amazed me were two things: 1. his exceptional animation skill, and 2. the fact that medical researchers are able to understand, and "map out" these processes, which occur literally at the sub-molecular level.
I always tried to impress upon my students the fact that these things actually MOVE, that they, somehow, "know" what to do, chemically sensing which other molecules to grab onto, how to "read" and copy the strands (transcription), moving without muscles and 'knowing' what to do without a brain or nerves . When one sees incredible animations like this, everything is lit up, and it's easy to imagine that within our cells there is somehow this level of ambient light, and LOTS of space. But NOOOOO!! IT'S ALL IN THE DARK!! lol
That we have folks like Mr. Berry and others who can make these amazing cellular mechanisms actually 'visible' to us is truly a blessing, helps us to apprecaite Life even more...and makes things a little easier for us lowly Science teachers! Thanks for sharing and bringing attention to this gentleman's work, and his (I feel) underappreciated contribution to Education.

Perfect illustration of the arrogance and hubris of microbiology. We are shown an incomprehensibly complex system with literally trillions of sub-microscopic moving parts - literally so small they can't be seen without an electron microscope. Our entire understanding of protein synthesis and cell division is just a narrative pieced together over the years from different measurements.  While we can see chromosomes through a microscope, we don't actually have video of DNA being split apart and copied by enzymes moving like little vehicles or robots. Maybe this is actually what happens, but no one knows. The pretty colors and the detailed animation make it seem as if we know exactly what is going on. We don't. But let's assume this paradigm in the animation is true.  The conclusion at the end of the video is absolutely ridiculous. Why would you assume that we will be able to make nanobots that "heal the body better" than the body can???  It's like if an alien spaceship were discovered intact and functional, and scientists studied it for decades and declared "we know how it works, and we can improve upon it."

The issue with nanobots has NEVER been the physical limit.  It has always been one of information.  How does one program these molecular machines?  They won't have an onboard computer. They can only perform one task in response to outside provided information (in the form of other signaling molecules, etc.).  The problem of life is, at its core, a problem of information.  Not chemistry.  Chemistry acts to kill cells UNLESS the information exists to drive these reactions in the "wrong" direction (i.e., to states of high free energy and low entropy) when unguided chemistry is constantly pulling cellular machinery in the opposite direction.  This is actually why there is pre-programmed cell death in the first place.  And why all these sophisticated control, error sensing and correcting feedback mechanisms exist in the cells.  But the origin of the information necessary for cells to do all of these things is NOT found in the laws of chemistry and thermodynamics that actually drive reactions the wrong way.

THE CURRENT SITUATION IN SPACE

SpaceX

The launch of 57 more satellites by SpaceX in the early morning of Friday, August 7, at 1:12 AM EDT, has brought the number of SpaceX’s “Starlink” satellites orbiting in the Earth’s ionosphere up to 595.

Although this was the first launch since June 13, SpaceX has not been idle during this time. It has built additional ground stations and has received permission from the Federal Communications Commission to operate (so far) 40 ground stations, scattered throughout the United States. It has signed up customers to begin “beta testing” of the satellites that are already in orbit. Beta testing will occur initially, says SpaceX, with customers who live between 44 and 52 degrees latitude in the northern U.S. and southern Canada. SpaceX plans to begin the testing sometime in September.

As I reported in a previous newsletter, SpaceX’s launch of April 22, which brought the number of its satellites up to 420, was accompanied by reports of heart palpitations from far and wide, including from yours truly. I again felt strong heart palpitations that began early in the morning on August 7. Actually I began to experience a feeling of oppression Thursday night about two hours before the launch time. Please contact me if you have been having heart palpitations since Friday’s launch.

OneWeb

OneWeb, which is based in the UK, and which had declared bankruptcy in March, has been bailed out to the tune of one billion dollars by the UK government and Indian telecommunications company Bharti Global. And on May 26, 2020, OneWeb applied to the FCC for permission to compete on an equal footing with SpaceX by launching 47,844 satellites into the ionosphere.

Although OneWeb’s offices are in the UK, none of its Directors live there. Its CEO, Adrián Steckel, is Mexican, and the rest of its Directors live in the U.S., Germany, Israel and Mexico. Its major stockholders are Qualcomm (Singapore), SoftBank Group (Japan), and 1110 Ventures (U.S.).

Amazon

On July 29, 2020, the FCC granted Amazon’s application to launch 3,236 satellites into the ionosphere. Like the satellites of SpaceX and OneWeb, Amazon’s satellites will operate at millimeter wave frequencies and use phased array technology to cover the Earth with focused beams of radiation enabling customers to access the Internet from anywhere on Earth, on land or ocean.

The satellites of SpaceX, OneWeb and Amazon alone, if they are all launched, will total, together, about 92,000 satellites. If you add in Iridium and Globalstar, which are already operating small constellations, and the plans of Facebook, Link, Canadian companies Kepler and Telesat, the China Aerospace Science and Industry Corporation, Russia’s Roscosmos, and other competitors, there could soon be 100,000 satellites orbiting in the ionosphere.

“But will you wake for pity’s sake”*

The out-of-control satellite industry is one of the stupidest things humankind has ever created. It treats the life-giving envelope of our atmosphere as if we don’t depend on it. It poses an immediate threat to life on Earth, in so many ways.

The 100,000 planned 5G satellites, each with a designed lifespan of 5 to 10 years, must be constantly de-orbited and replaced. This means that at least 10,000 satellites will have to be launched every year, forever into the future. If an average of 50 satellites can be launched on each rocket, that’s 200 rocket launches per year, just to maintain the satellites used for cell phones and Internet. And it means the de-orbiting of 10,000 worn out satellites per year, burning them up in the atmosphere and turning them into toxic dust and smoke. And that’s not counting the ever-increasing numbers of weather, research, tracking, monitoring, surveillance, military, and other kinds of satellites and missiles being launched in what will soon be a parade of rockets burning prodigious quantities of fossil fuels, punching holes in our atmosphere on a daily basis, and treating the source of all life as Earth’s largest garbage pit.

In the case of cancer when there is a mutation in the RTK receptor proteins know as HER2, where the receptor undergoes self dimerization leading to an overactive cascade of cell signaling which does not cease, this leads to uncontrollable cell proliferation thus becoming cancer. So a cell signaling specific treatment for this is an anti body known as Herceptin which binds to the RTK HER2 receptor to inhibit it from self dimerization. The antibody, in a way, acts as a nano bot to help our body since it can’t help itself against the mutation. Biology is so amazing!

As a design engineer in the field of electronics and software for 45 years, I see clear evidence of an intelligence that far surpasses human comprehension. These amazing “functional proteins”, usually referred to as “machines”, are extremely specific long chains of 20 amino acids, with typically over 150 amino acids per protein molecule. There are over 10^77th power non-functional combinations for every functional protein.
What makes it far more mind boggling is that every amino acid in the chain must have the same optical polarity (chirality). Every amino acid except glycine can have two polarities (like mirror images), and only one of the forms, the “L-configuration”, can be used in a functional protein. If a single amino acid has the wrong polarity, the protein does not function. We have no idea how protein molecules form with all the amino acids having only one polarity. It’s one of the greatest mysteries of life. And it’s true for every living cell on earth.

In order for the simplest cell to exist, it takes hundreds of different types of these extremely rare functional proteins (machines), each in large quantities, to come together at the exact same time and microscopic point in space, along with the functional cell membrane and many other components. The mathematical odds against the first living cells appearing by random chemical reactions in a pool of “pre-biotic soup” are overwhelming.
No chemist or biologist in the world has any idea how this could have happened by non-intelligent materialistic processes. It’s so unlikely it would be virtually impossible, even in an eternal universe.

The more we know about life, the greater these mysteries become. This is only one of many examples. We now have far less scientific evidence than ever to support an atheistic world view of the origin of life. Yet, most people are taught the opposite in the American public schools because of government control. It’s not “politically correct” to mention the idea of a Creator in public schools.

The Law myoho-renge-kyo represents the identity of what some scientists refer to as the ‘unified field of all consciousnesses’. In other words, it’s a sound vibration that is the essence of all of existence and non-existence, the ultimate creative force behind planets, stars, nebulae, people, animals, trees, fish, birds, and all phenomena, manifest or latent. All matter and intelligence are simply waves or ripples manifesting to and from this core source. Consciousness (enlightenment) is itself the true creator of everything that is, ever was and ever will be, right down to the minutest particles of dust, each being an individual ripple or wave. The big difference between chanting Nam-myoho-renge-kyo and most other conventional prayers is that instead of depending on a ‘middleman’ to connect us to our state of enlightenment, we’re able to do it ourselves by tapping directly into it by way of self-produced sound vibration.

On the subject of ‘Who or What Is God?’, when we compare the concept of ‘God’, as a separate entity that is forever watching down on us, to Nichiren’s teachings, the true omnipotence, omniscience and omnipresence of what most people call ‘God’ is our enlightenment, which exists nowhere else but within us.

When the disciples asked Jesus where the Kingdom of God is, didn’t he tell them that it was within them?

Some say that ‘God’ is an entity that can never be seen. I think that the vast amount of information that is constantly being conveyed via electromagnetic waves gives us proof of how an invisible state of ‘God’ could actually exist. It’s widely known that certain data being relayed by way of electromagnetic waves has the potential to help bring about extraordinary and powerful effects, including instant global awareness of something or mass emotional reaction. As well as many other things, it’s also common knowledge that these waves can easily be used to detonate a bomb or to even enable NASA to control the movements of a robot as far away as the Moon or Mars. However, none of this is possible without a receiver to decode the information that is being transmitted. Without the receiver, the information would remain impotent.

In a very similar way, it’s important for us to have our ‘receiver’ switched on so that we can activate a clear and precise understanding of our life, all other life and what we and all else that exists truly is. Chanting Nam-myoho-renge-kyo helps us to achieve this because it allows us to reach into the core of our enlightenment and switch it on. That’s because the sound vibration of myoho-renge-kyo represents the combination of the three major laws that underlie all existence.

Myoho represents the Law of latency and manifestation (Nature) and consists of two alternating states. One state of myo is where everything in life that’s not obvious to us exists. This includes our stored memories when we’re not thinking about them, our hidden potential and inner emotions whenever they’re not being expressed, our desires, our fears, our wisdom, happiness, karma, and more importantly, our enlightenment. The other state, ho, is where everything in Life exists whenever it becomes obvious to us, such as when a thought pops up from within our memory, whenever we experience or express our emotions, or whenever a good or bad effect manifests from our karma. When anything becomes apparent, it simply means that it has come out of the state of ‘myo’ (dormancy/latency) and into a state of ho (manifestation). It’s simply the difference between consciousness and unconsciousness, being awake or asleep, or knowing and not knowing something.

The second law, renge, governs and controls the functions of myoho, ren meaning cause and ge meaning effect. The two laws of myoho and renge, both functions together simultaneously, as well as underlies all spiritual and physical existence.

The final and third part of the tri-combination, kyo, is what allows the law myoho to be able to integrate with the law renge. It’s the great, invisible thread of energy that fuses and connects together all Life and matter, as well as the past, present and future. It is often termed the Universal Law of Communication. Perhaps it could even be compared to the string theory that some scientists now suspect exists.

Just as our body cells, thoughts, feelings and all else are constantly fluctuating within us, everything in the world around us and beyond is also in a constant state of flux, in accordance with these three laws. In fact, more things are going back and forth between the two states of myo and ho in a single moment than it would ever be possible for us to calculate or describe. And it doesn't matter how big or small, important or trivial that anything may appear to be, everything that’s ever existed in the past exists now or will exist in the future, exists only because of the workings of myoho-renge-kyo.

These three laws are also the basis of the four fundamental forces and if they didn't function, neither we nor anything else could go on existing. Simply put, all forms of existence, including the seasons, day and night, birth, death and so on, are all moving forward in an ongoing flow of continuation, rhythmically reverting back and forth between the two universal states of myo and ho in absolute accordance with renge and by way of kyo. Even stars are dying and being reborn in accordance with the workings of what the combination myoho-renge-kyo represents.

Nam, or Namu, on the other hand, is a password or a key; it allows us to reach deep into our life and fuse with or become one with myoho-renge-kyo. On a more personal basis, nothing ever happens by chance or coincidence, it’s the causes that we’ve made in our past, or are presently making, that determine how these laws function uniquely in each of our lives from moment to moment, as well in our environment. By facing east, in harmony with the direction that the Earth is turning, and rhythmically chanting Nam-myoho-renge-kyo for a minimum of ten minutes daily, anyone can experience actual proof of its positive effects in their life.

In so doing, we can pierce through even the thickest layers of our karma and activate our Buddha Nature (the enlightened state). We’re then able to summon forth the wisdom needed to challenge, overcome and change our negative circumstances into positive ones. It brings forth the wisdom that can free us from the ignorance and stupidity that is preventing us from accepting and being proud of the person that we truly are, regardless of our race, colour, gender or sexual preference. We are also able to see and understand our circumstances and an environment more clearly, as well as attract and connect with any needed external beneficial forces and situations.

Actual proof soon becomes apparent to anyone who chants the words Nam-myoho-renge-kyo on a regular daily basis. Everything is subject to the law of Cause and Effect, so the strength of the result from chanting depends on dedication, sincerity and determination. To explain it more simply, the difference could be compared to making a sound on a piano, creating a melody, or producing a song and so on.

The smallest functional protein in our cells is a very carefully constructed chain of 150 amino acids, each with it's own specific place, which then folds up into a very specific 3D shape. What are the number of configurations that can be made with the 20 amino acids that are used to make these proteins? What are the odds that just this one protein, using the "laws of physics", "magnetic attraction" , etc, of being formed?

10 to the 164th power. That's just one protein, the smallest one.

So if you were raised by atheist parents and taught to respect reason your while life, you will probably surround yourself by like minded people, and thus go your whole life without really thinking or pondering if there is an after life or if we were created or designed. A designer would not put a non believer through the most horror ever felt by anyone for an eternity - to do so would be direct evidence that their intelligence is limited and not capable of creating or designing people to begin with.

Last point, some have suggested that we are simulations living out our perceived life in a computer and unaware of its substrate or operating program. That over time we ourselves might develop the computing power to create our own mini-universes with simulations in a computer and those simulated people will be unaware of us. There is no way to dispute this theory, the same as their is no way to dispute the Christian Narrative. The only theory that is actually disputable is that all intelligent life arose from random chance evolution. There is simply not enough time for this to happen. The knowledge and information that is built into our bodies is simply too complex to come about via random chance. Mathematics, information theory, probability theory bears this out.

So in the end, what you choose to believe will be in large part pre-programmed into your head, by your parents, your culture and government. But if you choose to free your mind from bias, look at everything rationally, you can discover many wonderful facts about life.

If one were to "create" an animal or a human, they would put all the DNA inside the nucleus. The system currently used for mitochondria is antiquated, inefficient and messy, and prone to problems. That's because we evolved from underwater creature. The mitochondria is an afterthought we needed when we started breathing oxygen, and it stayed as a separate entity, probably a remnant of a weird bacteria infiltrated inside the cell. Very poor design, but very good evolution.

Another possibility for improvement: in the early stages of development we have palmed feet, because we used to be marine animals. This is such a waste, we build those webbed toes, and then we later dismantle them. If we were to design humans from scratch, we wouldn't need that.

There are countless such examples showing how evolution progresses very gradually and how we keep relics of our ancestors

People conflate 2 things: god, and the creation of life/humans. Those are different. We know humans were not "created" (see my other comment). Evolution is well established. But evolution doesn't explain the first few billions of years, nor what was before the big bang, not the multiverse(s).

There might be a "god", or a team of scientists, who launched a new universe by choosing a few parameters: speed of light, plank's constant, electronegativity values, quantum numbers and spins, ...
From those parameters came nuclear forces, and then water properties (quite fantastic those water properties), H-bonds and protein folding and life.

I read a comment below that basically said "Don't bring God up!" I find it fascinating how viscerally some people react, even before the concept has been mentioned, to the idea of a Supreme Creator. It's as if the commentor was already thinking about God as they watched the video. And who could blame them? The intricacies of life are so startlingly complex that only a fool would not recognize an intelligent design. I studied neuroscience in college and was profoundly impressed by the impossibly complex chemistry of life. You think vids like this are amazing? This vid does not even begin to scratch the surface of how much is going on inside even the simplest of cells.
I know that religion has a mixed history and that for that reason many people have chosen to eschew it entirely, but a true scientist does not discard any idea out-of-hand. Rather, they examine, study, and immerse themselves in every possible viewpoint until they discover the truth.
I also know that most people assume that such truth is subjective and therefore illogical, but I disagree; I believe that there is an objective truth beyond our feeble senses and that every religion is ultimately trying to uncover it through a mix of philosophy and revelation. If there is a God, it stands to reason that He would create some way for us to find Him, else why should we believe in him? We can witness his handiwork as we study His creations, but to reach out and contact Him directly transcends science, since a just God would not leave it to our differing scientific abilities to decide who can find Him and who cannot. No, a truly just God would make the path back to Him equally accessible to everyone, regardless of how much scientific training they have. Hence, science is not the answer to this question. It may serve as a confirmation to those who already believe, but it does not spark that belief by itself.
The answer lies in dedicating oneself to open-minded study and personal experimentation to see what merits or assistance religious faith may offer. Most people are too lazy to start that journey, but ultimately it is the only journey that matters since we are all just a few decades away from death anyways. So, if you haven't already, start the journey today!

At 1:27 the DNA entering the helicase should be spinning clockwise in sync with it's forward motion (corkscrew style). Moving as depicted in the video would involve cleaving the backbone at every twist, and we know helicase doesn't do that (helicase only unzips along the center). Somewhere else, backbone cleavage needs to happen to release torsional stress, and I'd like to see that animated.

Discourse to the Society of Theophilanthropists

It has been the error of the schools to teach astronomy, and all the other sciences and subjects of natural philosophy, as accomplishments only; whereas they should be taught theologically, or with reference to the Being who is the author of them: for all the principles of science are of Divine origin. Man cannot make, or invent, or contrive principles. He can only discover them; and he ought to look through the discovery to the Author.

When we examine an extraordinary piece of machinery, an astonishing pile of architecture, a well executed statue or a highly finished painting where life and action are imitated, and habit only prevents our mistaking a surface of light and shade for cubical solidity, our ideas are naturally led to think of the extensive genius and talents of the artist. When we study the elements of geometry, we think of Euclid. When we speak of gravitation, we think of Newton. How then is it, that when we study the works of God in the creation, we stop short, and do not think of God? It is from the error of the schools in having taught those subjects as accomplishments only, and thereby separated the study of them form the Being who is the author of them. . . .

The evil that has resulted from the error of the schools in teaching natural philosophy as an accomplishment only has been that of generating in the pupils a species of atheism. Instead of looking through the works of the creation to the Creator himself, they stop short, and employ the knowledge they acquire to create doubts of His existence. If life is a result of evolution, what mechanisms on a biological level ALLOW for evolution? It is literally as preposterous as the idea of God.

Really think about this, I understand the premise of evolution, but how can anything evolve while staying alive? Think in the context of the very first living cell. It must've been simple and lacking a LOT of basic functions necessary to survive for long... yet it did. Does this mean that it points to God necessarily? No.

How can a cell mutate while staying alive? It can not. Any errors or changes in the way that it would work would kill it. Especially replication errors: cancer.

How can a cell's offspring or replication mutate in a way that keeps it alive long enough to do it again and again consistently? Through chance alone. You believe that? That's fine, you have faith in that.

Think of the argument simply.
Take the island Darwin discovered the two separate bird species on. He claims that over time they evolved separately and could no longer interbreed. How does the first 'new bird' reproduce? Through a missing link species? Isn't that just... faith? There is no evidence of that species.

In the same way, there is no evidence that any single cell can have a missing link inside of itself that would allow for a change in the way that cell functions.

The only place we see that happening is inside of an Organism. That mutated cell surrounded by normal cells either lives and spreads its mutation or dies.
But for an individual cell? There's no such thing.

What I find amazing is that chemical engineering has always been looking for little tricks that allow us to avoid making tiny machines, and instead use huge batch processes that carefully tweak the conditions to give acceptable product ratios etc.. After all, we know that we just need to slap those two atoms together and we're done, but building billions of little machines is hardly economical. And yet, those tiny machines we've been avoiding are what makes us tick after all. It shows that the logistical issues of making nanotechnology viable at a large scale aren't insurmountable - it exists everywhere around us, with all its flaws and benefits. We've even been using them industrially for a while now, and they're pretty good at certain tasks.

Not that I'm implying that nanotechnology is a good way to do all engineering, but I'm going to spare us of those explanations :P

Feel free to correct me if I'm wrong but natural selection is when the copying of DNA during reproduction randomly causes changes or mutations in the DNA. These mutations can lead to the organism to having unique features that could either give the organism an advantage, a disadvantage or simply have no effect at all. The organisms with the advantage are more likely to survive and reproduce than organisms without the advantage or a disadvantage. This means that more organisms are born with this advantage. Over millions of years, all these random changes can lead to a new species forming. It is well known in science that all living things started of as single celled organisms. Some of these molecular machines are vital for the division of microbes and therefore could not have been formed from natural selection. For example, without the machine that copies DNA and spins as fast as a jet engine natural selection and division would simply not exist. It is the machine itself that fuels natural selection because it copies the DNA. I believe that something of such complexity as the microbe could not have formed from a bunch of molecules that happened to just randomly bond together in a very specific and complex way. For all the creationists using this as proof that it couldn't be random and hence not evolution, it is important to understand a few things.

1. Natural selection is not random. It is the process directed by the struggle for survival, that favours traits and the mutations that increase the organisms chances of reproducing successfully.

2. Properly defined, evolution is inheritable changes in the gene pool of a population over generations. So evolution does not occur to an individual, nor does it involve an organism changing into something else.

Basically, it is best to think of evolution as a sort of trial and error. An inheritable mutation that reduces the number of offspring that reach reproductive maturity, is not retained. That mutation was "trialed" and it failed. Whereas an inheritable mutation that results in an increase in the number of offspring to reach reproductive maturity, will see that mutation spread by the fact more offspring in later generations inherit it. This is what is known as natural selection, and it is not random, even though the mutations are.

Perhaps it might be a good idea for Derek to do a video debunking the misconceptions of evolution.
I would really like to see more detailed videos on those machines !!!

EVOLUTION works by the imperfect self-replication of life forms. When a population of life forms reproduces, a generation containing both imperfect (mutant) and perfect (non-mutant) life forms is produced. These various mutant and non-mutant life forms are then exposed to the survival environment. The heritable variations in these life forms affect the statistical likelihood of their success in creating their own mutant, further-mutant, and non-mutant offspring, which are, in turn, exposed to the survival environment where their heritable variations again may impact the likelihood that a third generation of mutant, further-mutant, and non-mutant offspring will happen, and so on. The somewhat haphazard accumulation of traits in a population as a result of this process ("evolution") is NOT "random," though it involves a great deal of chance.

THE PROBLEM IS that all evolution requires the imperfect self-replication of life forms. Thus, you need imperfectly self-replicating life forms to begin evolution. Where do you get these from? All such life forms known to us use DNA or RNA strands, ATP Synthase, little protonic batteries, and all the sophisticated panoply of micromachines to duplicate their defining molecules. Even if you strip it down to a creature using ambient energy directly and the most primitive nucleic acids to record some set of traits, you still need micromachines to replicate and apply those acids. Where did is all come from? Whence abiogenesis? We barely have a clue. The current theories are comically, pathetically inadequate. We do know one thing with absolute certainly, however: It did not arise by evolution.

The most amazing thing about those tiny machines is that they require information to do their job right. Where did they acquire that knowledge? Did they go to the International School of Molecular Machines? Or did they make countless trial and error attempts until they got it right? And how did they know they got it right? Is there some sort of feedback mechanism from the top-level organism which lets them know they got it right? And if they don't get it right, the overall organism dies and they have to start the process all over again, countless times, until the whole process eventually works, in uniformity, among the hundreds of thousands of different types of tiny machines which could not survive independently, but requires all the other nano-machines to interface and communicate perfectly with each other in a complex network of precise operations. And then, the top-level organism would have to know what types of nutrients these tiny machines require and in what quantities and then make sure they receive what they need at the right time. How would it know that information? Do the nano-bots pass that information back up to the overall organism in some manner? So what we are left with is a top-level organism that could not survive unless all those nano-machine are doing exactly the right thing, exactly at the right time, without error, and do it over and over, relentlessly, with incredible precision, and then, pass that acquired information on to succeeding generations of nano-bots so they could continue the process for billions of years. Look at the work of the recent Nobel prize winner of chemistry Ben Feringa.
"As a chemist, Ben Feringa is interested in molecular construction. ‘I am a molecule builder trying to construct smart molecules’, says Feringa. ‘Building a moving molecule is not that difficult in itself, but being able to steer it, have control over it, is a different matter.’ In 1999 Ben Feringa presented the first molecular motor, consisting of a molecule, part of which performed a full rotation under the influence of light and heat. He has designed many different engines since, even including a molecular ‘4-wheel drive’ car . By fixating the engine molecules to a surface, Feringa developed a nano ‘mill park’ in which the mills rotate when exposed to light. And last year he described the world’s first symmetrical molecular engine . Feringa also succeeded in putting these molecular engines to work, having them turn a glass cylinder 10,000 times their size."

Greetings all. What you are seeing are cyclic processors in operation at the cellular level. Life means cyclic processors exist in the system. This applies to all scales in an organism, not just the chemical nano-machines at the lowest levels. So, you don’t need an alien ecosystem to compare biology to, because our technology already supplies just such a contrasting family of systems. Being alive in biology, being alive in technology, or being alive anywhere else, means exactly the same thing - cyclic processors in operation.

Conceptually, you can think of a cyclic processor as a loop or repeating process. Cyclic processors are machines that take lots of energy to keep the cycle going, so you need a sizable power supply (and be able to dissipate the generated heat). Processors have a lifespan, which is how long the processor is going. To be alive, any system must have at least one cyclic processor operating. Suspension means the processor has stopped its cycle. Death means the processor cycle can’t be restarted. It doesn’t matter what the processor is made of, what its contained function is, or whether it’s replicating.

Let’s use an air vortex example. Air can blow down the street as wind, from high to low potential – this is not life. If a dust devil forms and moves down the street you have a simple lifeform. The difference is that a processor has formed. It takes energy, it keeps on going, it has a lifespan, and it repeats the same basic process again and again. You can kill it by either removing its power supply, or interfering with its processor structure. Simple life forms of all types are always coming into and out of existence. Complex biological life has a cyclic processor based factory to allow them replicate, and evolve over time.

All factories (from ribosomes to universal assemblers) are alive because they contain (or are) cyclic processors, not because they can manufacture or replicate something. Viruses are not alive because they have no processors – they use a living factory in a cell to copy themselves. A lot of the active machinery in cells is alive (simple life). The same is true of the [cyclic] electronic information processors in computers, [cyclic] software processes, or [cyclic] electro-mechanical motors. Most of the activity in technological systems revolves around various flavors of processors, which serve to animate the system (frequently ill-defined, but much easier to understand than biology).

For humans, cyclic processors define life and death – things like lungs, circulatory systems, and brains, need to be “kept going”. In other words – air processors, fluid processors, and information processors need to be kept cycling. This is a large part of what physicians are measuring with their equipment, and how they determine life and death. Robots (artificial animals) have their own set of processors you can start and stop, so life and death apply to them as well.

I think that these animations, while really good at showcasing how amazing molecules can be, also do a great job of misleading... younger people. The molecules appear to magically move from one motion to the next, such as the 'walking', but everything is actually moved by various chemical and electrical reactions, one after the other, in an easy to follow sequence. Not to mention all the molecules the animations leave out. It may give them wonder, but it also confuses them quite a bit. Like showing a ball marble moving through a Rube Goldberg machine without showing all the parts that react to move it along.

Now, this isn't your fault, nor even the creator of the animation's fault. It's just an unavoidable side-effect trying to explain something like chemical reactions in an easy to visual manner. Some things are lost in the translation.

it's all due to stochastic thermodynamic processes, the protein doesn't "know" it should walk, the way the arms fold makes the lowest (optimal) energy state to be each next step, and when a certain ligand is metabolized, another state is engaged and so on. imo it is really a mistake to call them "machines" because that term carries automatic associations of purpose and a "mission to accomplish". the proteins don't "want" to move, the cell doesn't "decide" to divide, it's all actually more similar to a stream of water running down a riverbed rather than an assembly  of machines. everything runs on gradients and energy imbalances, a myriad of proteins perform the task less than perfect, countless others perform above average, together their activity is distributed according to the governing impulse (local concentration gradients, temperature, pH gradients, electric potentials, etc.)

A little remark here: That's not "exactly" how it looks.

Molecular mechanisms work probabilistically. So the stuff is moving sort of randomly and it could go either way (or even fail completely, as it happens regularly in nature), but only has a better chance of doing one thing and thus that's what tends to have an overall effect (as these things happen millions of times).

The video just shows the straight path, when in "reality", some molecules should be moving backwards and some should be falling.

To those saying this can't be a coincidence, keep in mind that the origins of life were SIGNIFICANTLY less complicated than this. It is entirely the other way round to me; There is no magic here, no irreducible design, nothing was just put together like a piece of IKEA furniture, its all comprehensible reactions that we can trace through billions of years of lineage to the simpler mechanics of earlier life. It is undeniable evidence that nothing more was required, that if there was a god at all, it set in motion the universe and everything else came about from big ol clouds of hydrogen. There is simply no room for a god anywhere else.

You are literally watching physical, chemical, and biological processes, none of which require any deity to intercede. So how do you come to the conclusion that that is evidence that such a deity exists, rather than circumstantial evidence of the complete opposite? Religious 'logic' is (perhaps appropriately) really mystifying.

Watching a video like this 10 years ago definitely challenged my perspective on whether or not life arose from chance or from a designer. What is interesting is that DNA contains instructions for building proteins, but we need those very proteins to kick off the process of reading DNA to create those very proteins.

Also note that this video doesn't explain the origin of the DNA molecule. The RNA world hypothesis has major problems.

And finally, this video does not talk about the information contained within the molecule, and the specific sequence of the ATCG bases required for proteins, as opposed to just non-functional polypeptides, to be created. The information and sequence is an independent and abstract thing from the molecule itself, as its sequence is not determined by the backbone of the molecule. Think "computer hard drive" as the backbone, and an mp4 video file stored on the hard drive as the "information". They are independent things, as the hard drive has no bearing on the order of the bits that make up the video file, because any type of information can be stored on the hard drive. DNA and its information is similar. Its bits are the ATCG bases, and its sequence plays an essential part in function.

Regarding origins, we have never found complex, sequence specific, functional information to have been created by chance. From our uniform and repeated experience, this type of information always originates from an intelligence.

Finally, claiming that things like mutations and cancer and errors imply there is no creator or the creator is bad/evil only shows one's preconceived notion of what he/she believes such a creator SHOULD be like. But said person is not in a position to know the mind or intentions of such a creator. What if this universe is not the only reality, and death is one of a planned part? If that is a possibility, then claiming there is no creator or the creator is bad/evil would be making a claim too soon.

I'm glad Derek created a video like this. I plan to talk to him soon about the type of information contained within DNA, and where he thinks it originates.

Sorry for my english but, reading some of the comments i must say: Please do not make the mistake of thinking "this can't be a coincidence it's must be god right?".

This is not a creation, nor a coincidence. It's the RESULT of a natural process (The survival of the fittest), it's not magic.
Let's put it this way: The things that work (at least a bit) survive, the things that don't work do not. Repeat this process starting from super simple molecules through billions of years, iteration after iteration, billions and billions of "this has survived because it was better and this died because it didn't function in the right way".

Also keep in mind that there is NO ONE that decides "this works and this doesn't" it's simply because: if a "thing" survives, for various reasons that are given by how this thing is randomly composed, it almost surely means that it functions at least a bit better than a "thing" that doesn't survive. If you repeat this billions of times, more complex living creature will develop... and boom: Humans.
